The interview itself went well but they did not follow up with my as quickly as they said they would.
Interview Questions: Most of their questions were centered around transferrable skills.

title: Production Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: There is a phone interview, an in person interview, and a group interview. After speaking with one of the managers over the phone, I was scheduled to meet with another in-person. After the in-person interview you are scheduled to take a group interview with the entire department.
Interview Questions: Describe one time when you failed to complete a task.

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I got a phone interview for an Assistant Director at a professional school at the University that I attended. The interviewer was pretty rude and at the end of the interview, said I would hear in a week or so and that they wanted to fill it fast. I never heard. I knew the interviewer from having attended that professional school and saw them a couple times a few months later. They never told me I didn't get the job. It was posted for months and months and I saw that it was filled recently. No one ever told me, not even a blanket rejection from the University. I am extremely appalled at the poor way that the University of Chicago treats job applicants. You would think that as an alumni of the school, I at least deserved a two sentence email just informing me I didn't get the job. I think not telling people they didn't get a job after you interviewed them is highly unprofessional behavior and I am very disappointed with the University of Chicago.
Interview Questions: The first question was initially HR bounced your application because this job involves X and you don't do that so why do you want this job. It was a truly ridiculous question because the job description mentioned the work I do in my current job at least three times and my current job is very tied to the work they were hiring for. It made absolutely no sense and I remain confused about that question to this day.

title: Director of Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview process began with submitting an application through the online portal. The application consisted of a resume, cover letter, and writing / portfolio samples. Applicants are processed by the University's internal HR group and those that pass initial screening are recommended to the hiring committee. The hiring committee also has access to applications and can initiate moving applicants to the next stage. The next step after applying was a phone screening with three people with whom this position would work closely. After that was a one-on-one in-person interview with the head of the department/division. The final step was a full day of panel interviews. There were eight panels of three to four people each, ranging from student interns to tenured faculty to other staff members at various levels. The final interview of the day was with those to whom I would directly report.
Interview Questions: They were very interested in discussing the difference between strategy and tactics.

title: Program Manager, Data & Reporting Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process took longer than the interview process, 3 weeks total after the initial job offer. The interview process was good and thorough. There was a phone interview and 2 face to face interviews.
Interview Questions: How do I adapt to various workplace cultures? What's my favorite feature in Microsoft Excel? What would former colleagues say are my 3 strengths and weaknesses?

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was straight forward.  The lab manager brought you in and asked you questions that showed you were interested in the research that the lab you would be working in did.  Also a few questions about other extra curriculars that showed you have good time management skills.
Interview Questions: What other activities are you involved in on campus?

title: Marketing Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was fairly lengthy for such a junior position. I took part in a phone interview then two rounds of Skype interviews (since I was applying from out of state) and finally was flown in by the University for an in-person interview that lasted about 4-5 hours. The in-person interview turned out to be more of a meet and greet than an interview, though. Overall the process was fairly painless albeit long.
Interview Questions: How would you go about managing multiple vendors for multiple projects?

title: Inventory Planner Position Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Only had a phone interview, which went well until we got to salary.  They were 25% lower than I would have liked and no wiggle room. I did appreciate their directness.
Interview Questions: Tell me what you do?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: applied online and go interview email later. very basic questions like how well your experience matches the job and what's your career plan, and who your research and courses in school
Interview Questions: What is your experience on statistical package

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: I submitted an inquiry of interest to a graduate student via uchicago marketplace. I was asked to come by for an interview the next day. The employer had done his research on me beforehand and hired me on the spot. He asked me if I knew how to merge datasets on STATA. I didn't know how to, but said i did. The skill never came up on the job.
Interview Questions: Tell me all you know about financial markets.

title: Janitorial Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: In was on time, filled out the application, turned it in an waited to get called back for the interview. The lady that interviewed me was professional an pleasant to talk to. She asked me questions about what position I was looking for an  that there many positions open. Then she asked me a little something about my background work history, which then I elaborated and let her know what position I was looking for.
Interview Questions: What is customer service to me?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: He looked me up onlined and knew that I was qualified. He told me as much when I interviewed and gave me the job. He called me to Booth Business Center and was very helpful. Showed me his office and talked to me about his career. Very friendly and very nice.
Interview Questions: Do you know how to merge files in a specific statistical software package.

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: Email asking for a phone interview. Several days after the phone interview I was asked for an in person interview. Several days later I was made an offer. During the interview process I was asked to complete some sample tasks that were similar to the type of work I would be doing if I got the job. This was to see if I was a good fit and for me to see if I liked the type of work I would be doing.
Interview Questions: They asked how I was at handling a very busy executive's schedule/calendar/travel/etc.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: first i submitted a online application.  then i got called to do a phone interview.  i dd the phone interview. it lasted 40ish minutes. then two days later i got a call to do an in person interview. because of my location we choose to do a Skype interview.
Interview Questions: how do your experiences fit this role

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: There wasn't much in the interview process. A professor asked me about potential projects i wanted to work on and we discussed possible ones which would work well with my skill set. Professors here are very patient and willing to help.
Interview Questions: What projects do you want to work on?

title: Public Policy Research Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: After some greetings, the professor and his former interns asked me some questions about my school life and my interests in environmental problems. (The research is about environmental policy.) I briefly described my former experience in MUN, which is somewhat similar to researching, and explained my interests in marine resources preservation and environmental problems about PX factories.
Interview Questions: Why do you apply for this position? What do you find most difficult about writing a paper

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Phone call, face to face interview asked about resume and previous technical skills and different instruments used. It was pretty standard, not too difficult. The people are really down to earth and enjoy working here. There's some fascinating research going on here.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Assistant Director, Development and Alumni Relations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The entire hiring process took just about two and a half months, from website application to start date, and included a phone screen followed by two in-person interviews. Not a lot of communication in between.
Interview Questions: Tell us something that's not on your resume.

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: Received a call a few weeks after applying. Rather quick turnaround time. Met with the director; started off well enough. Things went South when I mentioned that in my current position, I worked closely with the equivalent office to where I applied. At that point, the focus shifted from me as a candidate to "Hey, how does the office at your current school do this/that?"
Interview Questions: I was asked about my current experience and where I saw myself in five years. I mentioned that I worked closely with other departments . Then, I was asked about a comparable office at my current job location and how it operates. The interview veered off-topic quite quickly. I knew at that point that I had no chance to get the job.

title: Associate Director, Development and Alumni Relations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Submit the application online. Then there was a phone screen with the hiring manager. After that stage, there was four face to face interviews with 1-2 people per session.  There was also a written test.
Interview Questions: Written test

title: Student Fundraiser Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: There was just one interview, in person. Submitted my resume online at their website, and got a callback fairly quickly. They told me about fundraising expectations (had to hit targets). The job was pretty simple, call someone and ask them a couple times to donate money.
Interview Questions: Behavioral- why do you want to do this job? Why would you be good at it?

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I had one skype interview, and one full day of in person interviews. All of it was pretty standard, no surprises. Everyone was a pleasure to work with. Having a employee refer me made a big difference. Many of these big universities never respond to applications, so having someone on the inside was a big help.
Interview Questions: Being interviewed by four deans at once.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: There will be a rigorous application process. You will likely do both one-on-one interviews and group interviews with several layers of management and maybe even students. Be extremely well-prepared with specific examples of how your past experiences make you a good fit for this role. Have flawless application materials and practice your behavioral interview skills before coming in.
Interview Questions: How would you sell this program to employers?

title: Radiology Tech Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I was called and asked a few questions over the phone.  Most were pretty basic which I thought was fine and went well as a ice breaker to get me even more prepared for the formal interview process.
Interview Questions: Where did I see myself with them in five years.

title: Research Assistant I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Very casual and informal. It was just the PI getting to know more about me and seeing why I'd be a good fit. It was a laid back situation and even the PI was telling me not to be too nervous.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your research experience

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied by sending a direct contact my resume. Within a week I got a response and was given interview dates. After the interview it took a long time to hear a response. I had already agreed to begin in another position.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself pursuing a future career? How would you describe yourself?

title: Clinical Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Remote Interview, simple very straight forward. Two people interviewed me, both 45 minute sessions.  They asked basic questions and it came very natural for me to answer them because of history of being a CRA.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. What kind of training did you receive as a CRA? Need some important items in the 1572. What is an ICF? What do you know about our company?? Why are you interested in being a CRA?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I worked in my previous phd advisor's lab, so there was no interview.I just asked my adivsor if he is willing to support me for another year. He is satisfied with my phd work and he wants me to lead the team to explore further in current research. So he immediately let me stay here.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, two days of in-person interviews, first with the senior team and then with junior associates. There was also a final perfunctory interview with HR mostly focused on salary. They did group, in-person interviews
Interview Questions: Can you describe your understanding of the ** center and its key initiatives?

title: Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was very laid back.You usually meet with different members of the department in one day. Make sure you read the job description beforehand and be familiar with what type of research they are currently conducting. Ask questions especially pertaining to their research and show interest in the position.
Interview Questions: How do you handle working with a difficult person? How do you stay organized? How does this role align with your goals? What do you hope to gain from this position?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Submitted application. Initially heard nothing but then was told by a department administrator that I was on the waitlist. After affirming that I would attend the school if admitted I was finally accepted off the waitlist about 3 weeks before the deadlines.
Interview Questions: No questions or interview.

title: Student Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied to work at one of the libraries on campus through the common library job system. The interview was basic and behavioral, with some focus on specific work requirements.
Interview Questions: How would you deal with a breach of confidentiality in the workplace? And what measures would you take to respect confidentiality?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: Extremely painless process, prompt callbacks, interviewers (hiring manager, doctors, HR recruiter and team) were not intimidating, extremely positive experience. Convenient location,  not the hustle and bustle of being downtown Chicago.
Interview Questions: Usual interview questions, "how do you handle conflict?" "how are you on learning new things?", "do you adapt to change well?", etc.

title: Research Associate Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with all department faculties. About 20 minutes per faculty. Visiting individual office one after another. Questions are based on previous experiences and future  plans on exeperiments. Some times I had to wait outside of office because faculty was too busy on the phone. After interview, they offered lab tour. They put extra efforts to show their equipments. Finally, I was escorted to chair office. He gave me an offer and I gave counter offer then deal was made.
Interview Questions:
What did you do previously?
Do you know ... (Protein of their interest)?
What you can do about it? 
Carrier goal?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I sent out lots of cold emails and eventually got a response. Interview will most likely vary by Professor but interview mainly involved just what kinds of software skills I had and how many hours I was willing to commit.  He also gave me the nature of the work. For the Booth school, salary seemed to be understood to be around $10-15 for undergraduates.
Interview Questions: Nothing unexpected. As I mentioned before, mainly software skills and how many hours I was willing to commit.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: initial  phone interview, then two rounds of in-person interviews which were both 3.5-4 hours long.  About a week after my second in - person interview, I received a call from the University asking me to provide references that would be contacted.  They were contacted, and shortly after they were i received an offer.
Interview Questions: What is your favorite excel function?

title: Senior Payments Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: Met with the Department Head and exiting Payments Supervisor.  They split questions between each other and they took turns asking me each.  It lasted about twenty minutes, so it wasn't drawn out as I thought it would of been.  Did lose 10 hours a month because campus jobs are normally 37,5 hours a week whereas in the Press, they are 40 hours a week.  :/
Interview Questions: Why are you leaving your current position?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: The whole process took two weeks. Firstly I got a phone call interview. After that, I was flied to Chicago to have an onsite interview, which took one day. During on site interview, I gave a oral talk and meet director, PI and other lab personnels. Overall, it  is a nice process and no stress at all. Everyone looks very nice.
Interview Questions: Basically, they ask your career goal? When can you start this position? How do you hear this position?

title: Index Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: One phone interview, two in-person interviews. The in-person interviews were with three different groups, the CEO, management and peers. The interviews in-person lasted about 2 hours each time. Everyone was friendly and welcoming.
Interview Questions: Please relate your skills to managing large data. Give examples of your attention to detail and a process you helped improve.

title: Clinical Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Simple 3 part interview- mainly just behavioral questions and q's related to capacity to handle workload. Met with primary investigator, other clinical coordinators, and staff. Overall, it was a pain free process. Some positions may require a writing sample- mine did not require it.
Interview Questions: Be prepared to explain any gaps in resume

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: Very straight forward and conversational. Phone interview, followed by multiple rounds of in-person interviews with various stakeholders. Always very respectful and conversational. The role was being developed as I was interviewing so it required a few extra steps as the actual position evolved and they determined the best fit for their organization.
Interview Questions: Why is this work important to you and how do you see yourself fitting in here?

title: Executive Administrator II Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: It was a typical interview.  I interviewed in two separate one on one interviews.  The first interview was an hour long with the person I was to support and the following interview was done with the hiring manager.  It also was scheduled for an hour.
Interview Questions: Typical questions.  Nothing unexepected

title: Research Specialist I Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: It's was a very simple and relatively easy process. The person who interviewed me was very genuine and made me feel at ease. The questions were typical interview questions like "Tell me about yourself" and "Why are you interested in this position?" She described to me the position that I was interviewing for and that took a bulk of the time.
Interview Questions: There wasn't really an unexpected question. Process was very basic.

title: Research Professional I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Promoted from Postdoc position. Had to give professional presentation for 1 hour and 1 on 1 interview with subject experts. I was impressed by the opportunity and projects and eventually took the offer.
Interview Questions: scientific question

title: Research Lab Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: It's really based on whether you know someone in the lab. The hiring is rarely formal or official. You just have to know someone in the lab that can tell the professor or their former manager. For big labs, there will be job posting on the university recruitment site.
Interview Questions: They ask you what you want to do after this. They mostly look for people who will pursue a grad school after this lab manager position, because they think it's an indicator of how motivated you are.

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: The position required a presentation.  Meeting with several directors and discussions about salary requirements.  Required more listening to the director instead of them learning about my past experience.  Not too difficult and received an offer.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a difficult situation at work and how you dealt with it.

title: Marketing And Communications Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: First round: phone interview with an HR representative. Standard behavioral interview questions. Took 3 weeks to hear about second round. Interviewed in person with three people in the department for 30 minutes each. Hiring manager did not any questions about me but was more interested in if I had questions. Was told id hear a decision for the next round in a week. Followed up and was told they were still in process. Never heard from them again with an official rejection.
Interview Questions:
What marketing ideas do you have for this role?
What do you know about our projects/initiative?

title: Research Professional Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by my boss to schedule a phone interview. When he called me he sounded very polite and made me feel comfortable. He asked me about my work experience and availability. We also discussed about salary. One week later I received another phone call and I was offered the job which I accepted. I am currently working for this employer
Interview Questions: Tell me about your work experience

title: Research Support Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very difficult to get, it was basically phone tag, followed by a lot of follow-ups. Finally got a phone screen, followed by an in-person meeting with the team. Was told I was a good fit by both the PI and the director. I have heard nothing at all regarding the interview or if  I had been rejected or accepted into the position for over a month. After emailing them, I got one of the automated denials, very unprofessional.
Interview Questions: They asked me what I didn't like about a certain job, but I swung it in a favorable light of the position.

title: Research Specialist I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Interview was relaxed; met with three people within the department and had a response via email in a few days. Everyone was nice and made me feel comfortable. Parking is difficult around U of C, so make sure to get there early unless you're going to park in one of the garages.
Interview Questions: The questions were pretty standard; nothing too difficult or odd.

title: Senior Data Warehouse Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: To begin with there was a 45 minute phone screen. Questions involved Oracle physical database structures and tuning, and later some data modeling and data warehouse design questions.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: I had previously met and worked with the professor I ended up conducting my research with. Interview consisted on a discussion of the projects and follow up with my dissertation committee as well as co-workers to verify skill sets. Networking in research conferences was very valuable to be able to secure this position, I built a professional relationship with the professor a few years prior to applying for the job.
Interview Questions: What projects am I currently working on?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions: Applied in February. I got contacted in March to pass initial phone interview. Got offered a face to face interview two weeks later. I passed second interview. a few day later, I was offered a third interview. I did not hear from them for two weeks. I received a rejection letter in the mail. Yes, a physical letter telling me I was not hired.
Interview Questions: List three positive traits that you do not have.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Very casual, went over the resume and the typical usual questions.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths/weaknesses?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: It wasn't that bad. I submitted an application online and I was surprisingly shocked that I received an email and phone back about 2 weeks later. Set up the interview. Two weeks after that I did my interview. Invited back for a 2nd interview after a week. Got an offer a week later.
Interview Questions: What is your greatest weakness that can affect the team?

title: Preservation Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Originally I was reached out to by my former boss via email. I came in for an interview right in the office. The atmosphere was friendly, and we mostly just walked through my resume to highlight things that would be applicable to the job. The rest of the office dressed very casually and seemed nice.
Interview Questions: How do you think this experience will fit into your career?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: You needed to submit reccomendation letters transcripts english language results and a personal statement. the hiring process is very selective 1500 applicants for 60 places.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Development Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2013
Interview Descriptions: Original post: First, a phone screen. Then, and in person interview in two parts covering the entire team. Some people were friendlier than others. I often received vague answers to my questions. The potential direct superior did not seem to have a good grasp of the position's responsibilities.
Interview Questions: What are the two most important things you have taken away from your current position?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Dec 2013
Interview Descriptions: Like most research assistant jobs, you probably got to the interview because you know the professor from class, or someone recommended you. I wouldn't sweat preparing for this sort of interview too much, just be confident and forthright about your skills and experience.  It is important to show that you are enthusiastic about the research, it would help to read some of the professor's papers or about the field they work in. You may have to meet with postdocs and grad students as well
Interview Questions: Do you know Matlab?

title: Graphic Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Contacted by HR, then came in at my own expense to interview in person.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Financial Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: two rounds of interviews with about four people each time. had an excel test with job related content
Interview Questions: usual questions--nothing out of the ordinary

title: Residential Computing Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2013
Interview Descriptions: I went to the College Housing office and was interviewed by two of my employers. The first assessed my activity within my college dorm house and my extracurricular activities. Then then proceeded to ask me a series of tech support questions and different scenarios concerning what I would do in each instance.
Interview Questions: What is the difference between a WLAN and a WAP? (probably hardest question)

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Nov 2013
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by email to schedule a Skype call. The Skype call lasted one hour. I got an offer one week later. Very positive experience. The interview focused on my career goals to check whether I am a good fit.
Interview Questions: What are your career goals?

title: IT Consultant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The interview is quite a easy and enjoyable talking with my interviewer. The questions are not hard, only to have a better understanding of your technical background.
Interview Questions: The best job you've done until now and explain where do you think you are the best.

title: Student Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2013
Interview Descriptions: Pretty causal. I discussed my cover letter with my supervisor. We discussed the time commitment of the job, what the job entailed. She really didn't ask me many questions, other than why I was interested in the job and some background information about me (I was a first year at the time). It was pretty straightforward and was the first job interview I ever had.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this particular job

title: Clinic Licensed Practical Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2013
Interview Descriptions: One interview hired the same day.
Interview Questions: None the manager that hired me, was very eager to hire me. But she extended my probationary period, and asked me to resign when i didn't want to do unethical things.

title: Desktop Support Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2013
Interview Descriptions: 1 Interview with the CIO and Desktop Support Manager. 1 Interview with other Department Leaders. Each was very different, CIO/DSM very Technical. Department Heads were more about personal beliefs towards helping others.
Interview Questions: Why did i want to leave the Private Sector, and work for a University?

title: Staff Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2013
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was different depending on interviewers. Some were very friendly but others were very aggressive. Overall it was very intensive.  There were 4 interviewers, with whom one should meet on different days.
Interview Questions: How do you see yourself for the next 5-7?

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: interviewed for a tech position in a large NIH funded project.  The employers always look for people who can commit to 2+ years, excel in getting the little things right and are enthusiastic about working in a large consortium project
Interview Questions: how would you troubleshoot a routine molecular biology experiment?

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2013
Interview Descriptions: I took part in a quick 5 minute phone screen. A week later I was asked to come in and meet the team in person. A week or so after that I was asked to come in again.
Interview Questions: Why am I interested in the position I applied for? They also had a few questions regarding some of the technical skills listed on my resume.

title: Research Professional Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: The interview process took about 2 months. Over that period there were two call interviews and one in-person interview. Since I'm out of the country, my flight and accommodation were covered for the short time that I was there. I had discussions with 5 people, sequentially, over a period of 5 hours (including lunch). The people, office and work culture are very similar to academia: very intelligent people (e.g., graduate students, post-docs, research professionals with high-level degrees) working in close proximity (cubicles or offices) who may be permitted to work flexibly (time) as long as it gets done before a hard-deadline (industrial-like).
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself, career-wise, down the road? He wanted to know in what working environment I would thrive in the most (e.g., academic, research center or industry and, in terms of role type, an independent research or service-oriented role)

title: Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Submitted an application online with a detailed cover letter. Got a phone call next week to schedule an interview. Had the interview the next week. It was 3 hours long, and I met with 6 people. Most questions were about my resume, interest in the particular area of administration, and my experience. There were a few behavioral questions thrown in as well. Overall very pleasant, professional and relaxed. Really interested in just getting to know each other.
Interview Questions: I had interned in a similar but different department at another university, and was asked why I was making the switch.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Long process
Interview Questions: Nothing Unexpected

title: Summer Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2013
Interview Descriptions: I submitted an application to the Conte Systems Biology REU program, which required a statement of interest and two to three recommendations.  About two weeks after the submission, one of the researchers in the Conte system called me to request an interview.  Since I was attending school at the University, I chose to hold the interview in person rather than over the phone.  About a week after the interview, my position for the summer was confirmed.
Interview Questions: Just general inquires about my interest and skills for the position.  Technical questions about MATLAB and Excel experience.

title: Operations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Mar 2013
Interview Descriptions: I began the process on-line.  This was the easy portion during the interview process.  You can check where you are in the process on-line.  Interviews were set up and I was brought back multiple times to meet different levels of Leaders.  A campus tour was added at the end.  Interviews were not intense but the frequency of them led me to believe that they were indecisive.  Some interviewers were late or did not show for the interviews which was frustrating.
Interview Questions: Questions were not difficult.  HR gives every interviewer the same questions to pull from so you are asked the same questions over and over again.  I picked up during the interviews that there were some people issues as well as lack of process issues.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: I think they asked some question like:- tell me something about you. tell me about your work history. what you liked about it and what you did not.I think they asked some question like:- tell me something about you. tell me about your work history. what you liked about it and what you did not.
Interview Questions: I think they asked some question like:- tell me something about you. tell me about your work history. what you liked about it and what you did not.I think they asked some question like:- tell me something about you. tell me about your work history. what you liked about it and what you did not.

title: Clinical Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: A long process because of how slow the company takes to get back to you. If you get the interview just be personable. Once they have chosen you for the interview, it's yours to lose.
Interview Questions: Can you sit for 80% of your day?

title: Accountant Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Dec 2012
Interview Descriptions: Initially contacted through email, had two rounds of interviews over 1 month, first round with staff, managers and directors and the last with the executive director. Friendly and easy going process
Interview Questions: Typical behavioral based, a couple technical

title: Communications Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the job via the online portal and received a call about a week later from someone in the department to set up a phone interview. The woman interviewing me was friendly and the interview was more of a discussion than a Q&A. As I learned more about the position and she learned more about me, we both sort of realized that it probably wasn't the best fit in terms of my knowledge of this particular department. A couple weeks later I received an automated email from the University of Chicago saying that I was not being offered the job, which was obviously no surprise at that point. But overall it was a good interview experience.
Interview Questions: What is your favorite book?

title: Research Support Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Applied online to uchicagojobs.com. I would say it took about a month to hear back, but once I heard back and scheduled the interview for a week after the call, the offer came 2 days after the interview and I accepted a day or two after. It was one day, I met with the post-doctoral fellow in the lab briefly, then the PI/Lead of the lab for an hour or two. Had a great conversation about our interviews/backgrounds
Interview Questions: Had I designed or performed any experiments using RNA interference previously?

title: Index Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: There was a first and second interview. Each time I met with the same people and each interview I desperately met with the CEO David Barclay, management Bryan and Erica and then a couple of analysts. Pretty general questions and prodding into what I already knew about their business.
Interview Questions: Can you tell me your experience in handling large data sets? Can you tell me your knowledge of Index and Data services

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2012
Interview Descriptions: Online application was followed by phone screening about 3 weeks later.  This was followed by an in person interview with one of the senior leaders.  The final interview was with 4 team members on the same day, but individually.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply for this position?

title: Instructor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was hired after a phone interview. It was a series of questions that assessed my competency as an instructor. There were plenty of questions to see my teacher philosophy. My classroom management was a big part of the interview because this is a middle school. My performance as a teacher was tested especially concerning showing proof with data to support it.
Interview Questions: What is your classroom management style?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: I contacted various PI's by email around my last year of Ph.D. work.  A prospective PI from UofC contacted me and arranged for an interview.  It took about two months before I first heard from the prospective PI and another two months to arrange an interview date.  The interview consisted of a face-to-face visit with him and several of his lab members followed by a presentation of my Ph.D. work.  The lab seemed generally happy and confident the lab's work was going in a positive direction.
Interview Questions: Nearly all questions asked were fairly straightforward.  The prospective PI didn't try to ask a question that would inevitably trap me giving an off-the-cuff answer.  Overall, the interview was a pleasant experience.

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview was pretty simple, not weird questions, just a conversation of my skills and experiences. I talked to the Principal Investigator and the Research Professional that I would be working under.
Interview Questions: I was in graduate school at the time of the interview, so they basically just asked me questions about my research project and other things I had done in the lab.

title: Admissions Counselor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions:
I completed a phone interview before being invited into the office for an interview day. During the "interview day" I gave a presentation on a single aspect of the University of Chicago college experience, had an interview with the Executive Director of Admissions Outreach, and my final interview was with the Dean of Admissions and his Chief of Staff. Overall it was a positive experience. Two days after my interview I received a call offering me the job. 

I was told prior to my interview that the Dean likes people with a lot of energy so if you possess that personality trait that's a plus.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to be an Admissions Counselor?

title: Development Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2012
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone screen from the HR department. It was very quick with a barrage of questions, none of which had to do with my resume or experience. Questions were mostly hypothetical "What would your last manager say was your best and worst characteristics; Give a situation where you last manager really challenged you; What is the biggest misconception people have about you and where does this misconception come from." There was very little said at the end which was disconcerting, and I did not get called back after wards.
Interview Questions: What is the biggest misconception about you and where does this misconception come from?

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: It is based on regular online application for PhD programs. Some faculties want to interview via Skype call if you are an international student. Otherwise you can come visit campus and CS department. CS department will pay one-way flight ticket for you.
Interview Questions: It totally depends on the faculty that wants to hire you as student. No general rule. In my case, it was after getting my offer. So it was just some explanations that what research topics are focused here and so on. Not actually an interview.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview is for the PhD program. one phone interview followed by a full-day on-site interview. For the on-site interview, I was interviewed by 6 faculties, each 30 minutes, I was also invited to their class and seminar. I got my offer 10 days after the interview, and I was asked to tell them my decision within a month. My suggestions for people who want to apply to PhD program at UofC: know what you want to study, and be familiar with the research the faculty is working on, and convince them that you are a good fit for them.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your research and your career plan

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: They flew me out. I slept, I woke up. It was an all-day affair. We started at 9am, roundtable interview with the committee. This was followed by a 30-minute interview with the chair. This was followed by an hour during which I could collect myself before my job talk. This was followed by a 45-minute presentation followed by an hour of questions. This was followed by a meeting with graduate students. This was followed by a two-hour break to collect myself. This was followed by dinner with two faculty members, driving in a car with them for 20 minutes, dinner and drinks for 2.5 hours, and then driving back to the campus lodging where they put me up. I flew back the next morning.
Interview Questions: Why would your research benefit from being completed at the University of Chicago?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: This is independent of U Chicago as I interviewed through my mentor.  I gave a research on my graduate research and interacted with the lab I was applying to.
Interview Questions: None.  The only questions pertained to my research.

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: First you do a single phone screen with three to five people.  That is not too bad.  If you pass the phone screen, you are invited to an all-day interview, with multiple sessions with people. This is a grueling process but allows you to meet many of the partners you'd be working with if hired.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.  They ask a lot of hypothetical questions and look for specific examples of how you handle complex work assignments.

title: Database Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions:
Good
Initially I had a phone screen with the recruiter, this was followed up with a phone screening with the hiring manager.  Finally I was asked to come on site where I interviewed with the hiring manager, and two potential coworkers as a panel.  
Finally I was asked to speak with the Executive Director.
Interview Questions: Personal and Technical Questions

title: Grant Writer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: A simple face-to-face interview was arranged after application to the job posting. The interview was on time and was conducted by a representative of a community outreach arm of the university. The interviewer asked about my writing experience and my availability to travel around the city, before describing the process by which government grants are applied for. The interview itself all in all was less formal than many large companies, with an emphasis making me aware of the general nature of the work.
Interview Questions: The interview asked if I had any prior technical writing experience, and if I knew the nature of grant writing.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2011
Interview Descriptions: My process had 2 steps including a phone interview and an in person interview before an offer was made. I met with 4 people in my in-person interview including the person who would become my manager.
Interview Questions: Nothing unexpected really. All classic interview questions about most challenging moments, etc.

title: Associate Director, Career Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2011
Interview Descriptions:
Immediate reply to application followed by long interview process.  Applied late November and received offer the following  March. Required several follow-up calls and communication to proceed to next step.
Offer was given too close to agreed start date--had only 4 days off in between jobs and was "invited" to attend/work an event one day before I started the new position.
Interview Questions: Required to write article as part of the interview process, near the end. Received no feedback, but was offered the position...

title: Web Design Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: Applied online through University of Chicago website. Was contacted for an interview via phone. Interview was 15-30 minutes and was offered the job. Accepted.
Interview Questions: What was the most success you had as a team?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: I contacted the lab PI via email and he responded immediately. First, we talked on the phone for about 30 min. Then he invited me to have an in person interview. The interview was one day long. In the morning, I met with the PI and chatted with him. Then, we had lunch together. After lunch, I gave my talk. And I talked to 3 other lab members. We also had a dinner with the lab members in the evening.
Interview Questions: why do you think you will be a good fit in this lab?

title: Editorial Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was quite easy. I was called in by the HR director, who was very helpful throughout the process. I had an interview with 3 other staff members, and then had to complete a writing/editing test. Questions were pretty simple--why are you interested in UChicago, why do you care about math, etc.
Interview Questions: What's a mistake that you've made, and what did you learn from it?

title: Intern In Lab Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions:
Contact by e-mail first, and do some research on the lab work, and do some preparation on lab skills.
Check the research projects and background. To know what exactly the lab will do, the field, the experiments, what former skills would relate to the future work, know some personality of boss, to avoid something he/she would not like to hear.
Interview Questions: What have you done in your former experience ?

title: Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions: The initial interview was over the phone, then it was followed up by an in person interview.  The phone interview was with the HR Director and then later on with the Manager of the Department.  The in person was the same just in reverse order.
Interview Questions: The standard interview questions were asked.

title: Systems Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions: A bunch of technical questions about administration of Linux.  Questions about network configuration using cisco hardware.  Questions about culture of administrator and academic culture.  Questions about webdev.
Interview Questions: How do you configure a rhel machine to use puppet?

title: Research Specialist I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions: It was a brief 2hr interview with the Management and the team and explanation of projects and description of project requirements. Meet the team and know individual projects and the possible collaboration.
Interview Questions: Related Experience

title: Patient Service Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jul 2011
Interview Descriptions: three parts, written, oral and meet the supervisors and wait  for a call back. after a few days went by and i did not receive a call back . shortly there after a received an e-mail saying that i was not the right fit for them
Interview Questions: what did i think patient confidentiality was and how did apply to me

title: Mlt Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions:
The interview was scheduled of a weeks time frame and various forms and per work were submitted and reviewed.
It was later followed by a panel interview and later notification followed over the course of the week.
Final notification and paper work soon followed prior to an offer being made.
Interview Questions:
Level of Experience
Reason for application

title: IT Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in May 2011
Interview Descriptions: initial screening based on on-line application.  phone screening.  interviewed by group and individuals.  slow process overall.  general review of resume and met with people from various departments.
Interview Questions: what was worst project implemenation experience.

title: Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2011
Interview Descriptions: I applied on a paper form and turned it into the office. I was e-mailed and asked to return for an in person interview.  The interview was one on one and questions were asked about campus knowledge and what makes a good university student. Hypothetical questions were also asked about working in an office setting.  Do your research on the programs of the school, including RSOs, majors, campus activities and things to do in Chicago. The office is friendly and it is a good mix of people from all aspects of campus.
Interview Questions: What would you tell a student who wanted to major in Econ?

title: Lifeguard Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2011
Interview Descriptions: Spoke with the aquatics director, and gave some basic information about my past experiences. After a brief personality review, I gave him a copy of my certifications.
Interview Questions: how would you deal with an unruly patron

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: Extremely long lag between application submission and contact; approximately 2 months of interviewing, offer and clearance, about 5 months total.
Interview Questions: Why would I want to take a position like this when I had more responsibility at prior positions?

title: CNA Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions:
In person interview- basic and easy...no prep needed
Drug testing & health review
Prepare for the process to take several weeks. It's big hospital and there is a lot of red tape before you can start. Worth the process for sure.
Interview Questions: Why you wanted to be in a patient care role and where you saw yourself in 5 years

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: on site interview with 9 professors
Interview Questions: Want to make sure that you like working in academia

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: Fairly standard format, broad range of potential colleagues, mix of development-specific questions and general getting-to-know-you questions.  For a near-entry level position, they were thorough and tough. They were looking for some background knowledge but also the skills to adapt and change.  The University has a specific culture that all applicants should be aware of: people are smart, quirky, and hard-working.  Look for topical news beyond what is just on the website home page.
Interview Questions: Do you excel more in the art or the science of fundraising?

title: Executive Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2010
Interview Descriptions: It took three months from that first phone call to my first day.  Initial phone screening wasn't a phone screen at all.  They just called me in for a panel interview with 4 people.  Then, the HR manager took a vacation and three weeks to get back to me.  Then they had to synch everyone's calendars and find a day that worked for a fleet of executives.  Second interview was a three-hour ordeal of successive half-hour blocks.  I still don't know why half of them were interviewing me!  After that, someone else took a vacation.  When they called and offered the position, they gave a start date a full month away.  Why is anyone's guess: I was unemployed and eager to work, and the position was filled by an internal temp.
Interview Questions: All questions were standard interview fare, particularly focused on customer service and negotiating difficult interpersonal situations.  Have specific examples ready, of dealing with tender egos or difficult people.  The university is full of them.

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2010
Interview Descriptions: I had two phone interviews, a skype interview and an in person interview.  I also had a 1:1 with the researchers friend.  The friend did quite a bit of background research on  me and showed me all of the information he found on me.  It was a little creepy but I wasn't nervous until he kept probing for questions as if I were hiding something, which I was not.  It was a strange experience, and after all of that time and effort, I asked them if they could give me feedback on the interview and they refused.
Interview Questions: What happened during (specific time) that you would like to tell me?

title: Desktop Support Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2010
Interview Descriptions: I responded to a job posting on the University job page, emailed the manager in charge of the posting and scheduled an interview. This was all pretty informal by the way, we chatted on the phone and arranged to meet that same week. The meeting was very informal as well, he asked a list of questions, we talked about interests and University culture. This last big was important to him and turned out to be important in general. You can't survive here if you are not comfortable with working in a fractured mess of relationships and fiefdoms.
Interview Questions: Pretty basic really, how would you deal with a failed local backup.

title: Research Professional Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2010
Interview Descriptions: job interview direct with the supervisor and previous research work presentation
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Advising Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2010
Interview Descriptions: I originally interviewed for an entry level management position and the hiring director asked me to instead apply for a lower level coordinator position. I flew in on my own dime because the director made it clear that they were not going to pay for the interview. I should  have taken that as a sign that she/he really thought that I would not actually fly in. My day began at 8am and ended at 5pm, 8 hours long! The hiring person was unfriendly, snobbish and seemed to have his or opinion about me already made up before I walked in the door. When I was asked "where did you park" I replied by saying on the side street and to that the hiring director responded "so you didn't park where I told you to park." Which by the way was a 15 minute walk from the building and begin that it was freezing and I was wearing heels I did what was smart.  Then for the string of interviews, I had to walk from one building to another to meet with several individuals and at one point I had a 15 minute walk from one end of campus to another. I honestly felt that I was being "hazed."  Later, I found out they hired an internal candidate who had previously worked with this unit and therefore completely wasted my time and in my opinion for the sake of meeting their quota of interviewing various people from different walks of life. Also during one part of the interview I was asked what high school did you attend? I after responding I was told ooh good for you that you made it so far. Seriously, HR written all over this.
Interview Questions: What ideas do you for the XYZ that will help carry out the function of this office?

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2010
Interview Descriptions: Found out about job opening at an event for undergraduate research positions in the fall. All labs with current openings described their research and their current needs. I approached the lab contact (a graduate student) for her email, and followed up shortly with my resume. I had an interview with graduate student in the lab the following week. I was offered the position and began within a month.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have working with children?

title: Receptionist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: This was the most stressful interview I've ever had.  The one-on-one interview was standard, but then an unexpected panel of 8 people in very expensive suits sat around a conference table and interrogated me for over an hour...for an entry-level receptionist position!  I was so uncomfortable with the environment that I decided not to continue with the interview process and left before I completed the computer skills test.
Interview Questions: How long will it take you to make a meaningful contribution to our department?

title: Barista At Ex Libris Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed at an informational session my first year at Hallowed Grounds. We were asked to fill out an application that consisted of mostly fun questions in order to gauge your personality. Afterwards, most applicants were interviewed on the spot. The interview was casual for the most part. Coffee shop interviewers were the general managers of the coffee shop, meaning older students.
Interview Questions: If you had to DJ, what kind of music would you play at the coffee shop?

title: Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: I applied through the careers web page of the university. I received an email within 2 weeks from the supervisor. I had a short phone interview to schedule a job interview on campus which took place 2 weeks later. I was interviewed by the head of the department, the supervisor, the HR manager, and the executive administrator. Questions were mostly about my qualifications. It took another month before I got a job offer.
Interview Questions: I had to explain why I wanted to change my field of research. I didn't want to move and I couldn't find a research job in my field in Chicago.

title: Web Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2010
Interview Descriptions: The interview was the standard questions: where do you see yourself in 5 years, describe your background, explain your resume, etc. The interviewer told me about the position and my role, and I then expressed my interest in the position and why I felt that I was the perfect fit.
Interview Questions: Do you curse?

title: Program Administrator Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: You don't want to know.
Interview Questions: How little are you willing to work for.

title: Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: I completed a paper application with basic information and a couple of short essays focussing upon how I felt that I could contribute to the environment within the department.  Interview attire was business casual.  Two interviews were conducted, one on a 1:1 basis, and another with a small panel.  The interviews each lasted approximately 20 minutes, and I was asked to run through my resume, outline any pertinent skills and express why I wanted the job, and what I could bring to the workplace.
Interview Questions: Outline your biggest weaknesses, and explain how you hope to overcome them if you were offered a position.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2010
Interview Descriptions:
The "Teaching Assistant" position at NSP is quite possibly the best part-time job college students at UChicago can hope for. The pay is around $11-12/hr, and you are working with inner-city youth. The hours are flexible since you pick which school/class/program you are able to work with.

First is the application-- which includes a lot of short answer essay questions. I would concentrate on highlighting working with kids in the past, and if you don't have that experience, highlight group activities and projects that required you to educate people, or at least have enormous amounts of patience (ie, if you were a director of a theater production, etc.) Once your resume is chosen, you come in for a 1:1 interview, which is really relaxed, but the most important aspect is to be as enthusiastic and personable as possible-- your future kids have to LIKE you in order to respect you and learn from you. A passion for education and helping others is a must. 

The office is absolutely great-- they are willing to work with you, and understand if you cannot work some days. It's really the best job, and working with kids beats stapling papers at the library or serving coffee by a long-shot.
Interview Questions: Do you like kids? Have you worked with children in the past?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2009
Interview Descriptions: After an online application (including GRE scores, transcripts and the like), received an interview offer letter (final offer also via mail), then contact with administrators back and forth several times to set up flights, etc. (was reimbursed for all travel expenses). Informally, interview process was from Th-Sat/Sun including lots of face time with current students and some faculty/admin. Formal interviews were 2-3 on Fri AM and 2-3 PM, including general background/fit stuff as well as why you want to go to grad school, what your research has been on thus far, etc. Generally, do you have the mentality and temperament of a scientist? I found out much later faculty also ask current students for any stand out candidates (good or bad) and take that somewhat into their decisions. Saturday evening there was a larger party at a faculty member's house with more socializing between faculty, current students and recruits.
Interview Questions: Nothing stands out as being particularly strange. Be prepared to discuss your research and ask at least one insightful question about each faculty member's research.

title: Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2009
Interview Descriptions: Submitted Resume on University of Chicago website. Phone interviewed with the profession, then a onsite Interviewed the professor and the lab members.
Interview Questions: I was asked to describe my thesis for my master degree

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2009
Interview Descriptions: The process was not very strenuous or tedious. Some of the panel's questions did trip me up a little, but the interviewers weren't too critical about my vague responses. After the interview there wa about a 3 day delay before I heard back about the position. Nice interview and place to work.
Interview Questions: What do you think will improve our company given ur limited knowledge about us?

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: Since I am still in the interview process, I can only comment on what I have experienced so far. I got the initial job interview through my recruiter at TekSystems. The first interview was with a senior business analyst and then with the project manager. I was asked pretty basic questions to gage my knowledge of the role of BA. The interview was conducted one on one and because I met with the senior business analyst first, I was able to better tailor my questions to the project manager. The 2 interviews lasted a total of about an hour and a half. To prepare for the interview, I went to geekinterview.com to get a list of some of the questions I would probably see for that position.
