After that, I wrote down my responses to each question and studied them over and over. I used mnemonics to memorize the different phases and methodologies, which proved to be helpful.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you were able to implement an idea that was not popular with the group? How did you sell them on the idea and ultimately, how did you get them to accept it?

title: Interactive Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2009
Interview Descriptions: Very relaxed and loooooong. The UC has a very old bureaucratic system in place where  a job has to be posted for so many days and have so many applicants before a hire is made. Its unnecessarily long and cumbersome and potentially hazardous to making timely hires.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in May 2008
Interview Descriptions: The principal investigator contacted me via email to set up an interview. I met with the PI first for a 1:1 interview. Afterwards, a longer interview day was set up with other team members. Within a few days, this was scheduled and I interviewed with 4 others who work in the lab (30 min/per interview/person), and phone interviewed with someone who could not be in that day.
Interview Questions: What is the greatest thing you learned at your previous job?

title: AVP-Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: 30 minutes. Virtual call with a senior staff member 1:1. Very straightforward and fair with a lot of context setting and overview of the new leadership style (compared to previous leaders).
Interview Questions: Expectations, culture, and examples of contributions to both in previous workplaces.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: The experience was good, interviewer is nice. Ask few behavior questions, need to prepare more technical answers. Over all is a positive experience. Talk more about your background, should be helpful
Interview Questions: what is your past experiences

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: the process was smooth and required multiple interviews on different levels which it takes probably a month or even more. The interviewers were nice and asking direct questions about the previous job experience and things learned.
Interview Questions: What is your previous job roles?

title: EPIC Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Be the first to apply! I believe that it's a rolling hiring process. Interview with two EPIC (Energy Policy Institute) pre-doctoral fellows. If I recall correctly, interview consisted of behavioral questions followed by a case study. Case study involved walking through your interpretation of a graph from a previous EPIC paper.
Interview Questions: What do you like to do outside of work?

title: Associate Director, Career Management Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: I enjoyed meeting with the team, and felt strong about my answers to their questions. They went silent after 2 rounds of interviews, one that required a lot of preparation/presentation, and wouldn't answer any of my email outreach, simply asking for a status update. That really didn't feel good. Finally answered a month later.
Interview Questions: How would you advise a student to follow up with someone they've been networking with, about a job, in order to not be too transactional in their approach?

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Series of one-on-one interviews with faculty. Watched talks by current students, postdocs, and faculty member. One night with dinner at faculty member’s house. Student-only meet and greet. Other opportunities to socialize with department.
Interview Questions: Describe your previous research experience.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I first attended a job mixer, then I was able to follow up with an in-person conversation with one of the recruiters. They provided me with helpful information on my resume format.
Interview Questions: What is one unique skill you bring to this position.

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The interview consisted of two rounds both where one hour long each. One was with the team of six advisers. And the other was with the two main directors at the office.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Assistant Dean of Students Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2023
Interview Descriptions: An initial 30-minute Teams call for my interest, followed by 3-hour Teams video interviews with different university constituents. A pretty standard process, but what I was extremely disappointed about was the follow-up and commitment of the institution making a decision. After being told an initial follow-up the next week with no response, I asked for an update and they said the process was delayed. After another week, I asked for another update, and they never communicated again which is extremely unprofessional.
Interview Questions: Standard interview questions about my interest and professional experience.

title: Development Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Succint interviews in timely manner Basic Development Questions for entry level role Formal dress Friendly interviewers - panel Multiple interviews - phone screen then in-person Focus on interview basics to prepare Ask them good questions
Interview Questions: What do you want to get out of development?

title: Business Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Few rounds of interviews with different people. Very easy! More like a conversation and everyone was super nice and relaxed. Biggest tip would be to be yourself and talk about your past experiences.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself & walk me through your résume.

title: Benefit Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: I was scheduled for a phone interview. On the day of the interview, at the very time of the interview, instead of being called for the interview I received a cancellation notice via email with no explanation. This was very unprofessional and inconsiderate as my time is valuable.
Interview Questions: The interview as canceled at the very time the interview was to take place with no notice.

title: Assistant Director of Programing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was pretty straight forward. I had four rounds of interviews all on Zoom. Questions were a little hard for an AD position and interviews were long but I powered through. Overall, a pretty nice experience.
Interview Questions: What is your methodology and motivation for applying for this position.

title: Grant Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Search committee was very friendly and engaging. Questions were appropriate for level of position. Very transparent about number of applicants and hiring timeline. Would have been a good opportunity but did not work out.
Interview Questions: Why are you seeking new employment?

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I completed multiple different interviews for the position. First, I had an initial phone screening, then a second phone interview followed by a writing assignment, and finally a virtual interview with five staff members.
Interview Questions: What was my interest in the University

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with the PI to discuss C.V. and goals. Then was invited for an in-person interview with the PI and the other faculty (around 5 PhDs) and support staff. There was also a comprehensive reference check.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Email exchange with professor going over responsibilities then a Zoom call with the other teaching assistants to confirm expectations and make sure we are set up in Canvas. That was all.
Interview Questions: Have you been a TA before?

title: Investment Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2022
Interview Descriptions: Initial screening process with their version of HR person. It then proceeds to the first 4 interviews with the Private equity team (not direct PE, it’s like a fund of funds). After that you get an additional 4 individuals to interview with. They will ghost you. I do not recommend applying for the position.

title: Education Staff Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Oct 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview was a short zoom call. The interviewers were friendly and had a selection of prepared questions. The conversation was natural and pleasant. They also followed up within an appropriate time frame

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Fast. 2 interviews. It was a straight forward process but I was a part of an interview event so that could have been why. I talked with HR first and then a panel of hiring managers.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Great, informing, welcoming, The interview process was very easy and smooth.
Highmy experienced in customer service. Achieved friendliness to ensure customer satisfaction. Use of numerous skills to train and lead others. Good work ethic.

title: Associate Director Interview

title: Kruskal Instructor Interview

Interview Descriptions: I applied online for the Technical Business Analyst role at the Center for Translational Data Science. The talent Acquisition Coordinator contacted me via email to schedule a phone interview to discuss my experience, professional background, and interest in working with UChicago BSD and the Center for Translational Data Science.
Interview Questions:
She literally verified my resume line by line. Not experience but timelines as if she was validating my answers wrt my resume. 
Q. Your resume says you did a second MS from XYZ university, from 2021 to current. Did you graduate?

title: Global Community Project Manager/Market Manager/Marketing Lead - Asia Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in May 2022
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with HR then with hiring team, offer within 2 weeks, fast and very kind people rejected the offer for the opportunity to grow in the company I was at, still not sure if it was the right choice
Interview Questions: tell me about your current role what would you bring how do you organize yourself how do you manage multiple projects

title: HR Generalist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: First, phone screen. This was with a friendly member of the HR team. Super easy and straight forward. Second, Zoom with three individuals. Then a seemingly easy case study. Following by you the candidate getting ghosted.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in working at UChicago?

title: Analytics Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Multiple interviews, very detailed, the interviewers were very helpful with information about the position. Had a starting interview with HR, then the director, a panel of leadership, then the entire team.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you had to offer constructive criticism

title: Summer Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: This was for a summer research internship. After my initial application, was given a data task. Once that was through I then had a zoom interview with two people. The questions here was a mixture of technical and behavioural questions.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your previous research experiences.

title: Ra Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Kind and courteous, descriptive, informative, and very efficient interview process. I was asked many questions about myself but felt very comfortable and appreciated the pace of the interview and the time I was given to disciss my qualifications.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: The first round is the data round which involves analyzing a climate-related dataset and asking you how the computation can be scaled to a larger dataset. The second round is an interview asking some empirical Econ questions.
Interview Questions: How do you estimate counterfactual results in an ideal world?

title: Clinical Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: It was a virtual email with one of the members of the research team. It went very smoothly and the interviewer answered all of my questions about the position and the patient population
Interview Questions: Tell us about research you’ve done in the past

title: Student Teacher Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Spoke with professor of the class. Met with her twice before starting. Before the first day, we met and walked through everything to ensure I understood how things would work.
Interview Questions: How would you inspire the students in this Biology course?

title: Backend Developer Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions:
First of all, UChicago has lots of departments with widely different practices when it comes to technical hiring. I know this because I interviewed at two departments at the same time and the interview process couldn’t have been more different.

This review is for my application with Globus. The other interview I had was with a department within UChicago Medicine, which is a separate company here on Glassdoor, so I put it there.

The first step was a take home assignment in Flask/Python. The assignment was to write a simple REST API, with the option of adding unit tests.

Once they review your take home, if you pass, they schedule a coding interview with a senior dev.

If you pass the coding interview they schedule a technical interview with the manager, who asks a design question to quiz you on architectural principles, as well as specific knowledge of authn/authz and other components of a distributed application.

Once you pass this stage there is a second coding + technical questions interview with another senior dev.

The final round is a 1-on-1 with the director of Globus, Kyle Chard, who’s extremely nice and pleasant to talk to.

I went through all these rounds thinking that the next step was going to be an offer, since I made it that far and had good rapport with Kyle. Alas, I received a rejection and later feedback.

The thing that seemed odd was that the feedback seemed to refer to a very small issue around the first technical interview. To be clear, my code ran, the issue was that I apparently asked a question or two of something that “should’ve been obvious”. I found this odd because I don’t remember struggling with the coding problem. My guess is that it was probably a close call between myself and another candidate but they had to come up with feedback that was better than, “we kept you interviewing for an additional 2 weeks because we were hedging the possibility that our preferred candidate left/got another offer.”

On the whole the experience felt negative because I was given a the impression talking to Kyle was the proverbial finish line, and I had no reason to believe I wouldn’t be getting the job. So to have invested all the time and effort and have it all swept from under me was incredibly disheartening/depressing.
Interview Questions: Easy to medium leetcode questions.

title: Assistant Director Facilities and Operations Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions:
I applied and was scheduled for a phone panel interview. The panel included a number of members from other teams which we would interact regularly. Everything about the panel seemed fine. A lot of boiler plate questions without getting into anything technical. I was told that I was a great candidate and they would be in touch the following week.

I sent four weeks' worth of check-in emails asking for an update in their process after that initial interview. The manager completely ghosted me. It was a pretty disappointing experience.
Interview Questions: The biggest ones of note were about your ability to interact with other departments or high-level administration, especially in an academic setting which can be highly challenging.

title: Financial Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: It was a smooth process. The recruiters were very helpful and encouraging as well as informative. I learned quickly about the position and the expectations. I gained knowledge during the interview.
Interview Questions: How do you manage your time?

title: PhD Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: It is focused on research. There are some tough questions to answer. But in general, if you get the interview, there is a high probability that you will get the offer.
Interview Questions: What is the main reference you are using in your paper?

title: Associate Health Physicist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Dec 2021
Interview Descriptions:
First interview was a call with the RSO and Assistant RSO. Behavioral questions and casual conversation to see if you are a good fit for working in the Hospital.

Second interview was a hour and a half meeting of the team and tour of the facilities they work in. They opened up the last 30 minutes for questions.

Very positive and comfortable interview experience. Everyone I met was extremely helpful and kind!
Interview Questions: Basic behavioral questions (why do you want to work here, strengths/weaknesses, how do you deal with tough people/situations)

title: Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: One round of behavioural interview and then a case. Two more interviews with the directors of the department. Fairly easy and actually pretty fun. Feel very respected as an applicant.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself and your life story.

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Preliminary 15 minute phone interview to check for surface qualifications. If you are a fit, then they move forward with full interviews. Who/How many you interview with depends on availability and with lab you are applying to.
Interview Questions: Really want to know you as a person and your skills. Asked questions pertaining to experience and personal goals to see if you are a good fit.

title: Assistant Department Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions: There are three interview committee members. They asked me questions and then I answered them.  The interview  was conducted in a traditional way.  They all dressed kind of casually and seemed very friendly.
Interview Questions: Tel  me about yourself and some behavioral questions.

title: Senior Research Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions:
A short, 15-minute interview for the first round with what seemed like identical questions for all candidates. Questions probed the resume and general interest. 

Interview was with entire committee which consisted of engineers and faculty in the division.

2nd round was longer (about 2 hours) but not much different. Time was allotted for a talk that showcased my skills.
Interview Questions:
Describe job X. 
How do you deal with people with "difficult" personalities? 
Are there any suppliers you wouldn't work with and why?

title: Covid-19 Contact Tracer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interviewers were kind, informative, and welcoming. The second interview was a group call. The con was that they never got back to me even though they gave me a time frame of when they would.
Interview Questions: What skills do you have that align with the job description

title: Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions:
I was asked a few questions about my past experiences in office work and customer service.
The interview took about 15 minutes and the person interviewing me was very nice. Overall the process was very easy and they asked me questions that are typical to a job interview.
Interview Questions: Describe a time in customer service where you had to solve a problem by yourself?

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Very thorough interview process. Everyone was very nice, welcoming, and responsive. Process was quicker than expected, and I felt supported throughout. Thoughtful questions and smart, motivated staff. Even though it didn't result in the outcome I hoped, I am grateful for the experience!
Interview Questions: What interests you about this role?

title: Deckhand Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: I had 3 rounds of interviews. The first 2 were each 30 minutes and were both 1:1. The final round was 2 hours and included a total of 6 people across four 30-minute sections. They completely ghosted me after my 3rd round. Regardless of the outcome, applicants that devote that much time deserve an update instead of waiting around.
Interview Questions: What's something interesting you learned about the school?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Going through the class and proving you knew the materials that were being presented so that I could offer insights and guidance to the students in the class and provide them with additional direction on how to manage the content and exams
Interview Questions: Are you qualified for the role?

title: Communications Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Needlessly drawn out and oddly-paced as if improvised. The position was not fleshed out well and it was not clear how it would interact with other positions or within the institution as a whole. After getting job (eventually), this was all confirmed.
Interview Questions: What do you know about U of C?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions: There was one interview over Zoom where they asked me standard interview questions - It was really casual and friendly. After the interview, I sent a follow-up interview thanking them and they told me they enjoyed meeting with me and asked for references. After checking my references, they offered me a position.

Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago

Behavioral interview and case study interview. 
Behavioral asked about my technical skills (i.e. programming skills I listed in application) and several behavioral questions. These questions include: 1. an example of convincing someone of an idea; 2. how I was convinced; 3. my takeaway from these experiences. 
Case study interview mostly asked about my previous research projects.
Interview Questions: 1. an example of convincing someone of an idea; 2. how I was convinced; 3. my takeaway from these experiences.

title: Project Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I submitted an application, resume and cover letter. This was followed by a thirty minute phone screening. The interview was followed by no information for several months. Poor communication throughout the process.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you worked between multiple constituents.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Overall interview process was pretty good. Got interview after applying online and set up a quick time to interview. The interview took about 30 minutes from start to finish and was overall smooth.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to do research?

title: Process Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Phone screening followed by one round of in-person interviews. Mostly conducted on a layback environment with professors and facility directors. Lots of technical questions and some behavioral ones. I received an offer about a month after the interview

title: Nurse Practitioner Interview

title: Data Analyst/Data Scientist Interview

title: Research Assistant Interview

title: Lab Technician Interview

title: Instructional Designer Interview

I had to prepare and deliver a presentation to several staff and faculty, after which there was a question and answer session. Then, I met individually with other instructional design staff and the head of the unit.
Interview Questions: Tell us a bit about yourself

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions:
First interview was an HR phone screen. It was more in-depth than usual phone screens. The interviewer was pretty neutral and was obviously reading a script. Be prepared to answer questions typically asked during second interview.

Then a week later, I was contacted for an interview with the hiring manager through Zoom. They were both very friendly and conversational. They did not run through the usual questions and instead seemed to be winging it. I found they interrupted me slightly. 

They let me know they were in the "early" stages of interviewing, and I heard nothing for 3 weeks until I got an email saying they went in another direction.

They definitely are banking on the university's reputation to bring people in, but it was slightly intimidating to hear statements like "We don't make mistakes." Kind of glad I did not accept the job because that is not a healthy environment, especially when they noted it is a new position working with a difficult software.
Interview Questions:
Tell me about a time when....

Why did you apply to the job/U of Chicago?

Describe a campaign when...

What can you bring to the position?

title: Environment, Safety and Health Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions:
A series of Zoom interviews over 2 weeks. Oddly, they didn't screen me first, then add on more interviews as the process went on.
The department has very educated personnel in research subjects, but most aren't educated in the ESH profession, nor is there anyone to mentor them so the personnel can grow professionally.  It is backwards for a cutting-edge institution. 

HR wouldn't share a pay range they were considering, but U of C is notorious for poor pay.  HR said it might take months for them to decide. That was shocking. It has been at least 2 months since I had contact with them.

They don't know how to be efficient with their time or mine.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Health Information Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The interview was a very sloppy affair. They called me without warning that I was considered for the job, less that I was going to be interviewed right there on the spot.
Interview Questions: Q: Tell us more about yourself.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: Varias preguntas relacionadas con tests en software y después varias relacionadas con estadística básica. El entrevistador era un profesor de la facultad de ingeniería eléctrica. Fue muy amable pero el perfil que buscaban no se parecía al mio por lo que no recibí ninguna respuesta.
Interview Questions: Varias preguntas sobre test de software

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: Usually the positions are lab specific, so the PI interviews you directly. After the first round, you progress to an interview with the most senior or relevant graduate students, which likely includes a presentation of prior work and technical questions about a potential project.
Interview Questions: What is your area of expertise and how will that benefit our lab's work?

title: Preceptor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: The interview is pretty straightforward. Asked to describe my academic past experience; sharing the teaching experience; went though the proposed courses that I may be able to teach.  No abnormal questions you would expect.
Interview Questions: the proposed courses that I may be able to teach

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Smooth and easy process, quick turnaround and responsive. information provided via phone and in person. Apply through the general website and may be interviewed by department too depending on the job you selected.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position? Why are you leaving your last job?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The process is multi-tiered and ending with whomever is the highest ranking person who will supervise your work. Very nice people, although a bit too U Chicago pleasant, but someone with a friendly professional demeanor will do fine there.
Interview Questions: They will have you speak with another researcher to get a sense of how you think about research.

title: Clinical Research Data Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: Panel style interviews. Three different and consecutive panel interviews. 1st interview: Head of Department and Clinical research managers and coordinators. 2nd Interview: Senior data managers. 3rd Interview: Junior data managers.
Interview Questions: Provide specific examples of how you tackled stressful situations. They will ask you about previous experience and how it can fit into your current role. Provide specific examples of what you bring to your knew position with skills from your past experince.

title: Registered Nurse, BSN Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: Interview went great, eveything went smooth and heard back from Interviewer fast will recommend to colleagues . I was nervous at first but as I was answering questions I became less nervous as the person interviewing me was making the atmosphere comfortable
Interview Questions: Why did I pick nursing

title: Instructional Aide Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: It was speed dating style. We were interviewed by admin and teachers. Each table asked a different set of questions. There were three of us interviewing for the position. Ultimately, two of us were chosen.
Interview Questions: Experience for the position in which I applied.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: I had a brief interview with the director of the program and discussed my past experience, my interest in the role, and answered questions about skills and basic behavioral questions.
Interview Questions: Basic questions about interest and past experience

title: Research Assistant/Interviewer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: The interview was straightforward, talking to direct coordinator and a supervisor at the same time. Mostly looking for genuine interest on subject matter, and indices for tact dealing with research participants.
Interview Questions:
- What would you expect that would be your biggest challenge on the job?
 - What would you do if a research participant is not cooperative?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Sending a Resume and an online interview. Followed by a data exercise. Present the results of the exercise. It is about market implied  volatility density function and visualized it using python
Interview Questions: Tell me about the delta of the option.

title: Community Relations Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The University of Chicago is a private research university in Chicago, Illinois. Founded in 1890, its main campus is located in Chicago's Hyde Park neighborhood. It enrolled 16,445 students in Fall 2019, including 6,286 undergraduates and 10,159 graduate students.
Interview Questions: What is your dog's name?

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2020
Interview Descriptions: Asked about research experience and education. Casual and very friendly.  It was a zoom meeting due to the virus. The interview was set via email and had a very quick reply. Zoom link and everything was sent prior.
Interview Questions:
What questions do you have for me?
What experiments and protocol did you do in your research projects?

title: Marketing Communications and Event Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions:
They use a 3rd party recruiting service (Hueman Your RPO Partner) that is extremely unprofessional. The recruiter was a) late to my call b) didn't know what position he was interviewing me for c) clearly had not reviewed my resume prior to speaking to me. Was told by him that I would move onto the next round and would hear back within a week. A month has gone by and never heard back from him - with multiple follow up emails sent and no response. 

I'm sure the University has higher standards, but Hueman Your RPO Partner 3rd party recruiting is a mess. I would not take too much time to prepare as they don't even know what they are hiring for. He took zero time to prepare for my call.
Interview Questions: Asked about my resume because he had never seen it prior to setting up the call.

title: Executive Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Recruitment team was very prompt in responding to e-mails.  Was asked to come in for an interview and to allow about and to allow about  1 hour.  It ended up taking over 2 hours.  I interviewed in a conference room with 3 staff members, one of which never looked at me, even after addressing me directly.  Was told that I would hear back within about 2 weeks.  After 3 weeks I received no response, and reached out to the recruiter to ask for an update.  I was told that candidates were still being interviewed and I would likely hear back within a couple weeks, but I never received communication after that.
Interview Questions: Are you willing to work evenings and weekends?

title: Finance Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was lengthy. I had a phone screen, zoom interview and then an in person panel interview. The entire process from phone screen to offer was about 2 months.
Interview Questions: I was asked a lot of detailed questions about my past job duties. These details were important for the particular role I interviewed for.

title: Senior Data Scientist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Excellent process.   First had phone interview.  Then interviewed with potential direct supervisor as well as their manager in a second interview. Had to take an hour long exam that was not too challenging.
Interview Questions: Interpret coefficients on a logistic regression example.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Got into contact with a Professor through email. I was asked simple behavioral questions and questions on past experience before getting the offer. The interview was also through email but met with Professor in-person too.
Interview Questions: What has been your experience with X software?

title: Summer Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2020
Interview Descriptions: A basic understanding of China-US relations is key. Also, you must know about types of green/sustainable energy and how they can complement/replace traditional fossil fuel-based energy sources. Just be candid about your experience and assuming it matches their criteria you should be fine.
Interview Questions: Tell me about the Belt and Road initiative?

title: Teaching Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: ask about previous experience. test skills and knowledge in the discipline I was supposed to teach. went to interview with 3 faculties. I then asked them about the whole job and the interaction with students, what was required and what was expected.
Interview Questions: What was your teaching experience?

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Mar 2020
Interview Descriptions: Very casual. They wanted to get to know me and see where my interests lie as well as future professional goals. Know how much time you will be able to dedicate throughout the school year.
Interview Questions: - Why am I interested in their research

title: Media Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Fairly straightforward - 3 rounds of interview with operations, exec director and supervisor.  However, once after the interviews, it took 3 months for them to make me an offer. Not sure if it's standard at Chicago but it was a fairly long, drawn out process for them to make me an offer.
Interview Questions: What's your level of expertise? How do you rate yourself when it comes to relationship management? How do you work with cross-functional teams?

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Public Seminar, 1-hour Chalk Talk, One-on-one meetings, Two dinners. The process was transparent and largely fun, if a bit high stress. My advice is to talk about science all the time. Come up with questions for each faculty member you will meeting ahead of time and be prepared to hash them out in person. If you don't understand a different faculty member's work that is outside of your area, do not attempt to talk to him or her about it but instead focus on your own research.
Interview Questions: Chalk talk was about presenting three future grant proposals. Focus on the scientific questions that underlie the theme of the grant and be prepared to be eagerly interrupted.

title: Internships Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Nov 2019
Interview Descriptions: There was two parts -- Zoom and in person. I was interviewed by two people and it was 30 minutes, each. It was a pretty simple process and received a response in 1 week.
Interview Questions: Describe your past experiences in their relation to this position?

title: Secretary IV Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: Initially I had a phone interview which was moreso a screening. From there I was invited to a 3.5 hour in person interview that included a panel and meeting with the heads of the department and one of the main doctors I would be working with. Speaking with them all really made me feel comfortable. I really wanted this job.
Interview Questions: What is one thing that you have intimated to help advance the company that you currently work for.

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I talked to the PI about wanting to conduct research as an undergraduate. He seemed pretty enthusiastic about me joining his lab and introduced me to the postdoc that I would be working with. She was the one who asked me most of the interview questions, which were mostly just to get a sense of my research experience
Interview Questions: What is your research experience?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions: I only had one interview for the position.  They explained the project, and the roles that I would have.  they  asked career related goals. The interviewer also allowed time for questions
Interview Questions: explain a time when you worked with a diverse group? Explain a time you were faced with a challenge, how did you address it?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: First discussed various job related items by email. Then got to campus and gave a talk and had some discussions with the PI. Met with other members of the group. Got a tour of campus.
Interview Questions:
what did you work on before? 
are you familiar with <relevant topic>?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I had a few Facetime interviews, since I lived out of state at the time. I spoke with graduate students and the professor whose lab it was. It was overall a pretty easy interview experience.
Interview Questions: What were the findings of your research study?

title: Registered Nurse, BSN- Cancer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions: Very  unorganized interview.  Interviewed in an empty patient’s room, not in a  conference room.  Questions felt like they were thought of on the spot, not prepared ahead of time.  A lot of discouraging  and negative info. about the position was divulged.
Interview Questions: Are you able to answer phones at the front desk, schedule the appointments for five or 6 surgeons, phone triage patients, set up and assist with some procedures.among a few other things and work 10-12 hour days 5 days a week.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Phone call with background questions, emphasis on details and comprehension of past work and it’s value, and then situational questions. 3-4 more interviews, 2-3 with the manager and physicians, each individually. Another, final, interview in group setting. Expect 5-10 people at this interview.
Interview Questions: What does a good day at work look like for you?

title: Communication and Campus Engagement Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone screening with my potential direct report. Then, I had to create a sample media report which took hours to complete plus a 500-word event description for an hour-long lecture. After I submitted these materials, I was invited to meet one of the directors of the department and the assistant director. Two weeks post-interview, I called the assistant director and asked for an update. She told me to just wait for their decision. However, that decision never came. I never even got a rejection letter and after putting so much time into the interview process, I thought this was very unprofessional. Would not recommend at least this department at UChicago.
Interview Questions: What is your background?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: interviews with current RAs, manager and PIs, discussed experiences and qualifications, interests after job, work environment and current projects as well as potential involvement for new hires. very low-stress, mostly just talking about the project and what I could contribute
Interview Questions: what is your past experience?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was lengthy. I met with the HR recruiter, director, manager and each team member. It was a full day process; and the process took a little over one and a half months.
Interview Questions: Careers goals

title: Physiology Lab TA Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Email the professor after taking the class. Build a good relationship with the professor, go to office hours, talk outside of class. The professor may even ask you personally to be a TA for the next quarter.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Abstractor/Coder Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2019
Interview Descriptions: Applied online; very easy application process.  Shortly after, scheduled a brief phone interview with the hiring manager then had a face to face interview a couple of weeks later with two department managers.

title: Director of Events Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Mar 2019

title: OM PhD Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Skype interview of 30 minutes.  I received an email notification in January about the interview, and received the decision in Feb. I was a little disappointed but that is how things work in grad applications.
Interview Questions: Tell me what your project is about.

title: Systems Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2019
Interview Descriptions: Garbage COO , very disrespectful. They called me back for the 2nd onsite interview. The COO tried to reschedule an hour before the interview after I had already taken  PTO from work to meet with them so I told them i couldn't. When I walked in got a bad attitude and was asked irrelevant questions- nothing to do with the job role or the school. I was not given a chance to ask any questions. The whole interview was very rushed- waste of my time. The others were very nice and I actually enjoyed speaking with them.
Interview Questions: High achievements in your professional career.

title: Senior Technical Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2019
Interview Descriptions: Slow and very cumbersome.  The website was difficult to use,  The process was a little bit humiliating. It was difficult to get a status of whether I was being considered.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your work history

title: Assistant Director, Graphic Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: Great! So kind, but lengthy, with a multi-round set of interviews. They dot their tees and cross their i's! But a wonderful and brilliant group of creative minds. They also require an in-person interview at one point.
Interview Questions: Experience working with  project management systems?

title: Research Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions:
Very fast process after the initial e-mail, although it took about 5 months between job application submission and the first e-mail reply.

Very professional, fast, and amicable HR department.

Both rounds of interviews were with a panel of people, first a group of 3 then 2.
Interview Questions: What is the biggest obstacle you think you would encounter in this role?

title: Research Lead Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was as expected, a bit drawn out. I had two interviews with the department, one was a panel presentation. Then an exercise and then an interview with the director of the entire chapter. HR took about six weeks to do my background check.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this role?

title: Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions:
I've interviewed a couple times for similar higher level administrator positions at the University and if you are not an internal or minority candidate forget about getting the job. And it doesn't matter if you are more qualified for the job than their internal candidate- thanks to the internet you can find out who was hired. The hiring manager will come up with a poor reason such as 'the internal person knows our current systems.' Nice lame excuse since it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out one accounting/HR/IT/etc. program to a different one. Overall, the University is scared of change and they have no desire to hire outside candidates.  As someone else mentioned they have to post a job and interview others in order to promote an internal person. I'm not sure why they waste external candidates' time (and their own) when a phone interview counts towards their recruitment efforts. 

Anyway, good luck to you. Most likely you'll have a phone and then in-person interview with multiple people.  And then you'll get the lame excuse rejection call/email.
Interview Questions: Standard questions- why are you interested, your experience and challenges you've faced. Questions will be tailored to the job.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Very quick one week after applying was sent an email about scheduling a phone screening. The process was very quick and easy. The interviewer was very responsive and asked the general questions.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was a longer one, meeting with 5 people in the office for 30-45 minute intervals. Many of the questions were repetitive between the people, with only slight variations based on their role in the office. The staff was extremely friendly and honest with their thoughts throughout the process.
Interview Questions: How do you manage working with people with different deadline approaches?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Relatively simple interview process, behavioral questions we the primary basis for interviews. Interviewer easy to talk to and kind. Wasn't grilled too badly seemed like more questions about fit within the department.
Interview Questions: Why academia?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Fast interview and meet with many professors during my time there. I do not have much experience but I still got the job on the spot which is pretty cool. Also the professors are really nice and chill and easy to talk to
Interview Questions: How much time can you commit?

title: Social Media Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2018
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process was a long and tiring for this position at the Harris School of Public Policy at University of Chicago. 
 
Made it through 2 phone interviews, 2 in person interviews and was not considered for the role.
Interview Questions: How would you rate Harris's current social media presence? What improvements would you make?

title: Clinical Informatics Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2018
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and interviewed with the fellowship director and a few faculty members. The process was extremely streamline and smooth. Got to meet a lot of the current faculty members and fellows
Interview Questions: Why do you want to do Clinical Informatics

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the role in the spring and received a request for phone screen the next month.  The initial phone screen was followed by a group interview, another interview with the hiring manager, and an oral presentation. Everyone was very nice throughout the process, asked thoughtful questions, and provided useful insight about the role.
Interview Questions: The interviewers were curious about my thoughts on future directions for the team.

title: Nurse Practitioner Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2018
Interview Descriptions: Informal setting, multiple interruptions during the interview . Did a 1:1 phone interview and a face to face then had to wait for other candidates to be interviewed . The interview was easy going. Hospital has great reputation.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. Why do you want this job?

title: Research Specialist I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview with the PI about a week after I applied online. Follow up interview with her and 3 of her colleagues for about 2 hours. One professor just talked about her research the whole time and another could barely come up with questions. I had to follow up after a week to learn I had not been accepted. No parking validation offered.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have with troubleshooting?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2018
Interview Descriptions:
Screening phone call first to assist potential for employment - 30 - 40 minutes. Covered career background and interest in position.
Second interviewee by phone with several people listening and one asking questions and responding.
Interview Questions: Does your background fit the position? Several questions on knowledge working with college students including international students and software for career services. About a 30-minute phone interview

title: Career Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2018
Interview Descriptions: Submitted the application online, the hiring manager will email you to set up a time for a phone call interview. They will call you at that time. the phone call interview is very conversational. no tricking question. mostly scenario behavioral questions.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself. walk me through your resume. why do you think you can be a good fit for this position? what do you know about our program/department? how would you gain knowledge and insight about the program/department?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Current students picked me up from the airport. We had dinner at a Thai restaraunt. In the morning we visited with several faculty members to discuss our previous experience and what our interests were. Then we went to dinner with our prospective advisors, and afterwards went to the campus pub for drinks with current students.
Interview Questions: What previous projects have you worked on and what do you want to focus on for your dissertation?

title: Billing Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jun 2018
Interview Descriptions: Multiple levels of interviews- with HR, Senior leadership and peers. Asked behavioral and situational questions as well as questions related to relevant job role. overall and easy process. was offered the role and I accepted.
Interview Questions: Behavioral questions and questions based on experience

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: 3-step process. Phone interview, In-person with three people, and offer.  Received a cold-call from the interviewer. Asked about my background and how I can contribute to the department.
Interview Questions: How will fund for your research?

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: I had 2  in-person interviews. Both were scheduled over the phone. They were average and quick. They talked about what they are looking for in the position and my background and its application in the role. The first interview was with my direct manager and the second was with the director.
Interview Questions: Why I am interested in this job?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: The PI asked me about my research and biology background. I then met with three other people from the lab for 20 minutes each, and then I had lunch with the entire team.
Interview Questions: What is your research experience

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Philadelphia, PA)
Interview Descriptions: 6 interviewers, all friendly, asked standard job market questions, gave some feedback to job market paper. They explained about the job and what was good in the position offered. Only couple interviewers looked enthusiastic.
Interview Questions: Explain your job market paper

title: Patient Transport Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Apr 2018
Interview Descriptions: Long but easy 3 management personnel asking patient experience questions. Patients are the main priority and time management and following of the rules and regulations of the company of you smile and answer all the questions right you got the job
Interview Questions: Patient negative experience you have had

title: Senior Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions:
HR Screening,
A face to face with the IT manager at recruiters office
Final face to face with the IT manager and former team member. Also met with the Director of IT operations
Interview Questions: I was contacted by a recruiter who prepped me up for the first level interview at the recruiters office. My background was discussed. I had to explain my past project and the technologies used. On the second level face to face interview at the work location, i was asked to advice on some real time problems in their work applications.I also had a chance to meet the IT head who asked me about the importance of process compliance and documentation.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow In Physics Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: Interacted with the PI via email. Had a phone discussion. Came to visit the university at which time I gave a talk. Meet other members of the group. Discussed physics with different people.
Interview Questions: What have you worked on before, etc.

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions:
Consistently bad experience.  Considering how esteemed the University of Chicago is, it is particularly shocking how inept they are at recruiting talent. Interviewed first with a project manager - not someone in HR or talent acquisition. Weeks later heard back and was asked to have an in-person interview with the hiring manager. 

After the interview, was told by hiring manager that she would be in contact within a week. She wasn’t. Was emailed six weeks later by hiring manager saying the HR system would be transitioning and that if I received an auto rejection letter, I should reapply via the new system (?!). She again promised to follow up within a week and didn’t. 

I emailed the hiring manager a week later and received a response email from the project manger (?) telling me to reapply via the new system if I was still interested.     

I’m not and I didn’t. 

Unsurprisingly, the role is still open and there are always jobs available at this place. Seems much more a bullet dodged than an opportunity lost.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job?

title: Medical Social Worker Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: 2 interviews; primarily hires from within; no discussion about salary during 1st interview; Very difficult to query exact salary level. I was asked about length of time in the field; asked about my preferences about hours, caseload volume & type; was asked to provide a short, written narrative about what diagnostic & treatment types I would recommend given a brief, short paragraph description of a hypothetical patient.
Interview Questions: I was asked about length of time in the field; asked about my preferences about hours, caseload volume & type; was asked to provide a short, written narrative about what diagnostic & treatment types I would recommend given a brief, short paragraph description of a hypothetical patient.

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the Cell and Molecular Biology PhD Program in the Molecular Biosciences cluster. Application was due late november, and there were 3 possible inteview weekedns in January and February. The interview was 3 days long, flying into Chicago Thursday night and going to dinner with current students, then 4-5 30 minute interviews with faculty on Friday, and brunch on Saturday with a student panel. The faculty were very pleasant, and the students were nice and outgoing, very friendly process overall.
Interview Questions: What are some experiences made you decide you want to go to grad school

title: Project Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2017
Interview Descriptions: I was invited to interview about five weeks after submitting my application for the role. Ultimately received an offer about a week after interviewing but chose not to move forward with the offer due to a lower salary offer than expected and the difficult commute to campus from other neighborhoods.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have with student/community outreach?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Dec 2017
Interview Descriptions: Consisted of one phone interview and three in-person, on-site interviews with matrix structure heads and with the faculty of which, you'd actually be supporting. Presented as a role to support 2 individuals and I currently support 7 faculty/executive's.
Interview Questions: Describe my top strength

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: I began by meeting with the hiring managers, then followed up a week later by meeting with a variety team members, and then concluded with f a third meeting to discuss the job offer.
Interview Questions: Describe the models of health behavior and education that you think are most effective for vulnerable populations?

title: Staff Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: interview with HR then with management. nothing too difficult, basically what you would expect going into a nursing interview in general.  May vary by manager, but overall nothing difficult
Interview Questions: Basic nurse questions, nothing extraordinary

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: I have interviewed with the University of Chicago three times and was ghosted by them twice. I took off an entire day to speak with a cast of 1000's, I sat in traffic for 45 minutes, and I had to pay for 8 hours of parking. The least you can do is respond to my emails and tell me I didn't get the job.
Interview Questions: Write of code and a graph explaining one of your past projects.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: I had an initial phone screening with the hiring manager followed by one in person interview with the hiring manager and two other team members. Both interviews were straightforward. They asked some general questions about my experience as well as behavior based questions
Interview Questions:
Tell me about a time you had a conflict at work. How did you handle it. 
What is your experience with Excel and databases?

title: Human Resources Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: It didn’t take two minutes to notice that they have an effete environment. I found the interviewer to be rather provincial and realized that they are only looking to hire someone cut from their same cloth. I politely ended the interview early and 100% sure I dodged a bullet on this one.
Interview Questions: Give us an example when you were on a project and had to take charge?

title: NSA Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: Hiring process wasn't bad, I filled out an application and received a call back less than 2 weeks later. Although I had been applying for over a year prior to my "big break."
Interview Questions: What would make me a good candidate for that role.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Basis RA interview with coding up some basic data manipulation tasks and then an applied write up of trying to forecast sales in an industry. The out of interview tasks took maybe three hours in total.
Interview Questions: How would you deal with computing ML when the data is too large to be held in memory at once (ie, you are doing high dimensional reg on stata on your crappy laptop)

title: Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions: I had such an appalling application experience (on multiple occasions) that I will no longer seek employment at the university. One example is that someone in HR reached out to me asking to set up time to talk, but then never returned my emails-- even blowing off a call that they told me they were available for. I would reply, wait up to a month for a response, then this cycle continued until I stopped getting responses. Strange considering they reached out to me expressing interest. I have also been told I would hear by the end of the week and didn't hear until a solid 2 weeks later, and by email even though they told me to expect a call. I had these experiences both with recruiters/HR and hiring managers.
Interview Questions: Tell about a time when you helped someone at work.

title: Program Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions:
Day 1: Submitted application online (I am/was an external candidate with no connection to UChicago whatsoever)

Day 6: Invited to participate in a phone screen with HR, which occurred the following day

Day 7: Spoke to HR on the phone screen for 25 minutes (The screen was pretty typical-I've listed the actual interview questions below. The HR rep was very personable and the actual conversation was as pleasant as phone screens get. Toward the end, she said I would be hearing back in a couple weeks. The morning after I followed-up with a thank you note and HR followed up with their own email thanking me for my time)

Day 28: Three weeks had passed since our conversation so I followed up with an email. No response. 

Day 40: I looked for that position on LinkedIn and saw that it was filled by an internal candidate.  I then looked on UChicago Career site and said the position had been filled. That status must have changed overnight because I had checked the previous day and it read "In Process"

Though the interview/phone screen was nice and informal, I would've liked a 'ding email' just for the sake of closure. I have the feeling that my phone screen was just a courtesy so that HR could say that they looked for external candidates. I was very well prepared and answered the questions thoughtfully--I don't think I ever really stood a chance.
Interview Questions: Can you walk through your resume and give me a brief overview of your expertise?

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions: Casual, only asked basic interview questions. A few specifics about my experience and previous jobs. I was called for a second interview. Also two more quick conversations on the phone.
Interview Questions: Your weakness

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: I was asked to do a phone interview, which I completed almost immediately. It was very short. I never heard back from them. Sent a follow up email thanking them for the interview, no response. Sent another follow up email 3 weeks out and they said the position was filled. It would have been nice to have been notified.
Interview Questions: What interests you about working here?

title: Admissions Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions:
I showed up for the interview early because street parking can be a nightmare. I met with the HR person who took me to the 3 person interview. The person who was to be my main boss looked bored and kept looking out the window. I never felt like I had the direct manager's attention and that they were "elsewhere".

I didn't really talk much and they kept diminishing my current employers worth and boasting about the wealth of the University. I don't remember there being any actual questions, just being led into talking about my current role.
Interview Questions: I wasn't asked questions... just fed information to work with.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was extensive, they try to cover as much possible and most of the time it is a multiple people interviewing you. People who are going to be working directly with you are most likely involved in the interview process.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths and weaknesses

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL)
Interview Descriptions: Brief first interview followed by several interviews with various team members. They expressed interest and I was repeatedly told I would receive an update shortly.  Then silence. No response to email inquiries, nothing. The job remains posted as open.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Chicago
Interview Descriptions: Interviewer dependent. PI was rude and condescending. Asked about my background as stated on my resume - which I was fine with - but as soon as I would speak, would cut me off and say 'ok, anyway.'  He then gave me a brief run down of the work environment/duties and then ended with a misogynistic speech.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your background

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: Was contacted for a brief phone interview than asked to come in the following week for an in-person interview with other coordinators and the PI. It seemed like it went really well and they told me they'd be setting up another interview with a PI who was out of town for my in-person interview. I didn''t hear anything after that. I had emailed them a couple days after the interview inquiring about when the phone interview would be and they never responded.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Chicago in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions:
There was an online application first, then a phone screen with HR. This was followed by 2 video call interviews 1:1  with  manager and multiple 1:1 interviews with potential teammates. This was all completed remotely. 
Offer came after expressing offer from other company.
Interview Questions:
Strengths to be brought to the team?
How would you handle relocating for the position?

title: Secretary Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jul 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied online; then had a request for a phone screen interview. About a week after the phone screen, the hiring manager followed-up with a request for an in-person and on-site interview at the university office.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here? How is your experience tailored to this position?

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Chicago (Chicago, IL) in Jun 2017
Interview Descriptions: Keep this in mind before applying to roles in ARD: UChicago has a policy that in order for an employee to be promoted, they must post that higher title position online. This means you're often applying for a job that may not actually be available, but UChicago has to interview three candidates EVEN IF this is a role set aside for someone else.
Interview Questions: They asked pretty standard questions, but if this job is set aside as an internal promotion, it doesn't matter how well you answer these questions. I would try to find out if an internal candidate is being considered or if this is a truly open role before wasting time in a four-hour long interview going nowhere.
